image.altText: Piles of miscellaneous goods laid out on a wooden floor.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Over $1m in stolen goods sold on to community markets in alleged drug-trafficking scheme. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Police have charged a man with trafficking dangerous drugs after he allegedly sold heroin in the Darra area, in south-west Brisbane. Police executed a search warrant at a Darra house and linked restaurant where they allege they located a quantity of dangerous drugs. Police also recovered over $1 million worth of alleged stolen property including tools, high-end designer fashion clothing and accessories, electrical goods, alcohol, firearms and a substantial sum of cash. A 61-year-old Darra man faces a number of charges including one count of drug trafficking. He will reappear in the Richland Magistrates Court on November 8. It is alleged that some customers were paying for drugs with stolen property which were then on-sold to the community through local markets. Investigations are ongoing including identifying owners of the stolen property.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police claim stolen goods sold onto markets recovered in alleged drug trafficking scheme

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Toxicology reports have confirmed a Queensland man who died of a suspected snake bite did not have any venom in his system. Donny Morrison was attending the 100th anniversary of the Koumala State School, south of Mackay, on Saturday evening when another man had a brown snake wrapped around his leg. The 68-year-old grandfather was struck multiple times in the chest and arms as he removed the snake and took it away from others at the celebration. More details here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Snake bite ruled out as cause of grandfather's death by coroner

featuredLink.title: Snakebite ruled out as cause of death of beloved grandfather as coroner finds no venom in system

children.content: Toxicology reports have confirmed a Queensland man who died of a suspected snake bite

another man had a brown snake wrapped around his leg

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea's state media agency KCNA has reported Kim Jong Un invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to visit North Korea during their meeting in Russia, which Putin has accepted. KCNA reports Kim has expressed a willingness to foster stable, future-oriented ties with Russia for the next 100 years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Putin invited to visit North Korea following meeting with Kim

featuredLink.title: North Korea's leader vows full support for Russia's 'just fight' after viewing launchpads with Putin

props.alt: Russia's President Vladimir Putin and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un

North Korea's state media agency KCNA has reported Kim Jong Un invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to visit North Korea during their meeting in Russia, which Putin has accepted.
KCNA reports Kim has expressed a willingness to foster stable, future-oriented ties with Russia for the next 100 years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's jobless rate is forecast to stay roughly steady, when the Australian Bureau of Statistics Labour Force data is released this morning (at 11.30am AEST). A Reuters poll of 26 economists has forecast the unemployment rate to stay at 3.7%. The unemployment rate ticked up slightly to 3.7% in July, when the economy shed 14,600 jobs. In an analyst note, ANZ said it expects the decline in jobs last month to be reversed, with employment up about 30,000. ANZ is forecasting the unemployment rate to tick back down to 3.6%. Out of interest, here's a chart showing what's happening with the unemployment rate over the past five years. See the peak in June 2020 at 7.5% and where it's got to now!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unemployment rate to stay at 3.7%?

children.content: Australia's jobless rate is forecast to
stay roughly steady

The unemployment rate
ticked up slightly to 3.7% in July
, when the economy shed 14,600 jobs.

ANZ is forecasting the unemployment rate to tick back down to 3.6%
Out of interest, here's a chart showing what's happening with the unemployment rate over the past five years.
See the peak in June 2020 at 7.5% and where it's got to now!

props.alt: A chart showing Australia's unemployment rate, peaking at June 2020 at 7.5% and now sitting at 3.7%

children.content: (Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Department store Myer has reported a full year statutory net profit after tax up 23%, to $60.4 million. That's up from $49 million the previous year. The result comes despite a tougher second half of the financial year, as cost of living impacted consumer demand. Total sales were up 12.5% on the previous year to $3.3 billion. Myer's chief executive John King said it's the retailer's best full year sales result since 2005. "Our multi-channel offer is a key strength of these results as we capitalised on customers returning to stores after closures in the prior year, underpinned by our leading customer loyalty proposition in MYER one. Our online offer is a scale business that returned to growth in the second half and has continued to increase market share throughout FY23." He says online sales make up about 20% of total sales, at $690.5 million. Online sales have grown 163% since pre-COVID times. The company will pay a final dividend of 1 cent per share, taking the total financial year dividend to 9 cents per share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Myer posts best annual sales result since 2005

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Housing demand seems insatiable, but home builders are collapsing amid a "profitless boom". According to ASIC, more than 1,700 construction companies across Australia entered administration between July 2022 and April 2023. Parts of the country have also been beset by construction delays and contract terminations. Read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why are builders collapsing despite huge demand for homes?

featuredLink.title: It's been called a 'profitless boom' — why are builders collapsing despite huge demand for homes?

children.content: Housing demand seems insatiable, but home builders are collapsing amid a "profitless boom".
According to ASIC, more than 1,700 construction companies across Australia entered administration between July 2022 and April 2023.
Parts of the country have also been beset by construction delays and contract terminations.
Read more on this story here:
